column1: 48;"https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/friedrich-merz-soll-als-blackrock-lobbyist-viermal-bundesminister-getroffen-haben-a-1249428.html";2019-01-23;"Merz soll als Lobbyist viermal Bundesminister getroffen haben";"Der frühere CDU-Fraktionschef Merz hat laut einem Bericht enge Kontakte zu Vertretern der Bundesregierung - im Auftrag der Finanzindustrie.

Bei der US-Fondsgesellschaft Blackrock ist man offenbar zufrieden mit Friedrich Merz. Der Aufsichtsratschef darf auch nach seiner gescheiterten Kandidatur um die CDU-Spitze weitermachen. Womöglich hängt die Zufriedenheit auch mit den guten Kontakten des früheren Unionsfraktionschefs in die Spitze der Bundesregierung zusammen.

Als Interessenvertreter des Vermögensverwalters soll Merz viermal Minister der Bundesregierung getroffen haben. Das berichtet die Nachrichtenagentur dpa unter Berufung auf eine Antwort der Bundesregierung auf eine Anfrage des Linkenpolitikers Fabio De Masi.

Zweimal traf Merz in seiner Funktion als Aufsichtsratschef des deutschen Blackrock-Ablegers demnach den damaligen SPD-Außenminister und Vizekanzler Sigmar Gabriel (17. Oktober 2017 und 7. März 2018). Am 12. September 2018 kam Merz den Angaben zufolge mit Finanzminister Olaf Scholz und Staatssekretär Jörg Kukies (beide SPD) zu ""Finanzmarktfragen"" zusammen. Das vierte Gespräch habe mit CDU-Kanzleramtschef Helge Braun am Rande einer Präsidiumssitzung des CDU-Wirtschaftsrats am 26. April 2018 stattgefunden.
Linke: Bundesregierung muss Abstand halten

column1: 83;"https://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/after-angie-what-comes-next-for-germany-s-conservatives-a-1236841.html";2018-11-08;"The Beginning of the Post-Merkel Era";"Angela Merkel's recent announcement that she would step down as the chair of the Christian Democratic Union has opened up a race for power that could define the future of the conservative party and the country. New elections could be next.
When Friedrich Merz went to bed on the night of Oct. 28
column2: he was certain that his old rival
column3: Chancellor Angela Merkel
column4: would announce the next morning that she was stepping down from the leadership of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). He had just finished watching the results from the state election in Hesse and seen the CDU plunge 11 percentage points relative to its result in 2014.

column1: Merz has been a political insider long enough to know that Merkel couldn't simply ignore the result
column2: particularly after the center-right had done so poorly in Bavaria just two weeks previous. And for days prior to the Hesse election
column3: his old CDU allies had been calling to encourage him. Finally
column4: after 18 years of waiting
column5: the moment seemed to have arrived for which they had been waiting: the end of Merkel's tenure as chairwoman of the CDU.

column1: And that is exactly what happened.

Merkel's announcement that she would withdraw her candidacy for CDU leadership ahead of the party's December party convention released a dynamic that immediately changed the entire architecture of the country's political framework. The leadership battle in the CDU had long been simmering. Now
column2: it has burst out into the open. For almost two decades
column3: internal party democracy had been frozen
column4: Merkel's grip on leadership tight and unyielding. Now
column5: though
column6: there are several candidates who have thrown their hats into the ring to determine the future course of the CDU -- and nobody in the party's leadership can control what will happen next.

column1: More than that
column2: few in the party believe that Merkel will remain chancellor for long following the CDU convention in December -- no matter who emerges victorious in the race to succeed her.

column1: The Closing Act
But the race isn't completely about who will end up leading Germany's strongest party in the post-Merkel era. It is also about revenge
column2: about delayed gratification and about whether the clock can be turned back. Merkel is not only giving up a party office -- her political legacy is at stake.

column1: What has now begun is the closing act of an extraordinary story
column2: the German version of David versus Goliath. Once upon a time
column3: a trio of men thought that it was up to them to lead the CDU out of the era of Helmut Kohl. It seemed guaranteed that Friedrich Merz
column4: Roland Koch or Christian Wulff would take over leadership of the party and
column5: later
column6: of Germany. The future was clear before it had even arrived. But then came the fall of the Berlin Wall
column7: and Angela Merkel
column8: who cleverly took advantage of a major party donation scandal to take control of the CDU. For the trio of men from the West and their supporters -- the so-called ""Andes Pact"" -- Merkel was little more than an accident of history. They couldn't believe that a woman who learned her politics in the East would suddenly be steering the CDU ship. And that this woman would modernize the party to such a degree that it no longer had much to do with the CDU as they had come to know it. ""Unfortunately
column9: Merkel has no feel for the party
column10: complained one senior CDU member at the time. ""We
column11: on the contrary
column12: grew up within the party. We know what the CDU is and what it is not.""

column1: In other words
column2: it isn't just old personal wounds that are now fueling Merz and his supporters
column3: even if such wounds are plentiful. They also have a problem with the new direction the party took under Merkel -- the slide to the left and the abandonment of traditional positions like support for nuclear energy and mandatory conscription. ""If the CDU gives up pretty much everything that it considered right and proper for decades
column4: then we shouldn't be surprised if our core voters turn away
column5: Merz wrote fully 10 years ago.

column1: Now
column2: he wants to become CDU leader to correct all of the mistakes that he believes Merkel made as party chairwoman. And in doing so
column3: the 62-year-old Merz is fulfilling the longing many party members have for the good
column4: old CDU: conservative
column5: pro-business and preferably masculine. Health Minister Jens Spahn
column6: although he is 24 years younger than Merz
column7: has a similar image of his party. And then there is CDU General Secretary Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer
column8: who is seen as Merkel's favorite
column9: in part because she has tended to support the course Merkel has charted.

column1: Merkel
column2: though
column3: now realizes that she no longer has any influence over the direction her party will take or over how much of her legacy will remain. She also senses that her tenure as chancellor could come to a much quicker end than she would like. Back in 2004
column4: when then-Chancellor Gerhard Schröder gave up leadership of the Social Democrats to Franz Müntefering under a similar situation to the one Merkel now faces
column5: she blasted the move as ""a complete loss of authority"" and ""the beginning of the end."" She knows that the same could now apply to her -- which is why she had been hoping to the very end that the Hesse result would turn out better than it did.

column1: Indeed
column2: there are now significant doubts about the story that her decision to step down from party leadership had long been planned and was completely voluntary. There was
column3: in fact
column4: a group of conservatives surrounding Wolfgang Schäuble
column5: the president of the German parliament
column6: the Bundestag
column7: who intended to pressure her to step down if she didn't draw the consequences herself. Schäuble had even told his friend Friedrich Merz to decide by the Sunday afternoon of the Hesse election whether he wanted to campaign for party leadership or not.

column1: Growing Pressure on Merkel
But the Merkel opponents within the party had begun preparing for the end of Merkel's leadership long before that. Back in March
column2: at the funeral services for Cardinal Karl Lehman
column3: many of the members of the old Andes Pact expressed to each other their frustration with Merkel and the fact that
column4: despite the extreme difficulties she had had putting together her current lackluster government following the general election one year ago
column5: she had given no indication that she was preparing to make way for a new generation. They thought that it might make sense to challenge her leadership at the upcoming party convention. And they quickly agreed that Merz would make a perfect challenger -- and they began pressuring him to take on the role. One of the most important things that Merz had going for him: the support of CDU eminence grise Wolfgang Schäuble.

column1: He didn't just give Merz advice
column2: he also sought to open doors for him. In mid-October
column3: Merz traveled to Brussels for talks with important politicians and officials
column4: and Schäuble managed to arrange a meeting for him with Joseph Daul
column5: the French head of the European People's Party
column6: the center-right group in European Parliament to which the CDU also belongs. But not long later
column7: Daul warned Merkel that Schäuble was working on behalf of Merz behind the scenes.

column1: The chancellor was unimpressed. ""Schäuble has a new candidate every week
column2: she said. But it was the moment at which Merkel must have realized that her opponents were serious this time.

column1: Merz was a frequent visitor to Brussels during this important phase. On Oct. 10
column2: for example
column3: he went to the fall reception of the Deutsches Aktieninstitut
column4: a financial lobbying organization. The next morning
column5: he met with Günther Oettinger
column6: Germany's European commissioner and also a member of the Andes Pact. Oettinger also encouraged Merz to think about running for the CDU leadership should Merkel pull back. Oettinger felt that Merz would make a good successor because Merz had also once been a European parliamentarian and held similar views on European policy as he did. Merz told Oettinger that he wanted to wait and see how the conservatives performed in the state elections in Bavaria and Hesse.

column1: Oettinger was far from the only one who encouraged Merz to take the step. Another member of the Andes Pact
column2: the former governor of Hesse Roland Koch
column3: also pushed him to think hard about running to become the CDU's leader. They had the impression that Merz wanted to take the step but was wary of the risk involved. ""His preference would be for the party leadership committee to unanimously request him to run for the position
column4: one ally joked.

column1: Still
column2: Merz's allies were unsure if the timing was right. They were looking ahead to the Hesse election and felt that if the CDU's result fell to 28 percent
column3: they would be able to move forward to pressure Merkel to resign. Just to make sure
column4: Schäuble placed an op-ed in the influential conservative weekly Welt am Sonntag on the day of the state vote. Typically for Schäuble
column5: the text wasn't about Merkel at all
column6: but about Max von Baden
column7: the German chancellor who dethroned Kaiser Wilhelm II on Nov. 9

column1: That moment
column2: Schäuble wrote
column3: was ""the perfect lesson for choosing the right moment in politics."" Von Baden's hesitation had ""increased the pressure that led to the revolutionary events of Nov. 9
column4: Schäuble wrote
column5: adding that von Baden's tenure as chancellor was a lesson that the right moment in politics ""is usually only apparent in hindsight. And that doing nothing can also have consequences.""

column1: Hidden Messages
Merkel's allies have become experts over the years in decoding the hidden messages delivered by long-time adversary Schäuble
column2: knew immediately how this particular history lesson was intended: as a demand that Merkel hand over leadership of the CDU.

column1: When the results from Hesse began rolling in that Sunday evening
column2: it quickly became clear that the CDU was in trouble
column3: even if the party would likely still remain in power in the state as the head of a coalition government. That evening
column4: Schäuble's son-in-law Thomas Stobl
column5: himself a deputy leader of the CDU
column6: flew on behalf of the anti-Merkel group to feel out whether the time was right to push her out.

column1: But Strobl's mission was in vain: Merkel gave no indication that she was preparing to resign from the post. Shortly after the first results from Hesse were announced
column2: Kramp-Karrenbauer met with Merkel to ask the chancellor how she should respond to questions about Merkel's future.

column1: What should I tell the journalists?"" she asked. ""Has your position changed?"" Merkel told her that her conviction that the positions of party chair and chancellor must be held by the same person -- as she had recently told the daily Augsburger Allgemeine -- had not budged.
A short time later
column2: Kramp-Karrenbauer went before the cameras in the foyer of CDU party headquarters in Berlin and said: ""The CDU party chairwoman has been very clear that she intends to run again at the party convention.""

column1: The Decision
Not even 24 hours later
column2: though
column3: Merkel stood at the same spot and delivered the exact opposite message
column4: saying she would not run again to become party chair. During the press conference
column5: Merkel didn't make a big deal of the fact that she had just completely contradicted herself. Yes
column6: she said
column7: the decision ""is a significant deviation from my deeply felt conviction."" But
column8: she added
column9: she still felt the ""risk"" was justifiable. She seemed completely in control and not at all agitated
column10: as though she had accepted her fate.

column1: Since when have I been thinking of this step?"" she asked rhetorically. ""Since before the summer break.""
And indeed
column2: she had been thinking about it for some time. There are very few people who Merkel consults about questions of such existential importance. But one of them is Annette Schavan
column3: the former education minister. On the last weekend in July
column4: right in the middle of the parliamentary break
column5: Schavan traveled to Hohenwalde
column6: a town just short of the border with Poland
column7: to visit with Merkel at her dacha. This is where Merkel spent much of her summer vacation this year
column8: forgoing her usual trip to South Tyrol.

column1: During Schavan's visit
column2: the two them discussed potential future scenarios
column3: and both were convinced that conservatives were facing steep losses in the upcoming state elections in Bavaria and Hesse and that pressure on Merkel would continue to rise. The two women considered how Merkel could justify giving up the party chair position if need be while at the same time hanging on to the Chancellery. Merkel
column4: though
column5: secretly hoped that it wouldn't come to that
column6: as can be seen from her subsequent comments to the Augsburger Allgemeine.

column1: But ultimately
column2: she saw an increasing number of indications that her rival Friedrich Merz wasn't just thinking of a candidacy but was taking concrete steps. The plan she had hammered out with Schavan was becoming more probable all the time.

column1: Merkel likely made her decision on the evening of the election in Hesse. Critique of her leadership from state chapters of the CDU had begun trickling into the Chancellery and the rumor that Merz was intending to challenge her for party leadership was solidifying. It became clear to Merkel that a debate about her position as party chair would erupt in the coming days and she couldn't wait for the party leadership retreat scheduled for a week hence. She had to take action if she wanted some modicum of control of the unfolding situation.
On Monday morning
column2: just minutes before party leaders were set to gather to discuss the Hesse result
column3: Merkel walked into Kramp-Karrenbauer's office and told the general secretary that she was not going to run for re-election as CDU chairwoman. For a moment
column4: Kramp-Karrenbauer was speechless.

column1: A Period of Anarchy
In the meeting a short time later
column2: Merkel had hardly informed party officials of her decision before a representative of Friedrich Merz informed the mass-circulation tabloid Bild that he intended to run.

column1: That put the pressure on Kramp-Karrenbauer. She had actually hoped to wait a bit
column2: feeling as she did that a sudden announcement was somehow disrespectful to Merkel. But she was concerned that the Merz train could quickly gather momentum. So she held a long speech about the tepid results from Hesse and spoke of the problems that the CDU had to address in the future. And finished her remarks by saying: ""That is why I am running for the position of chairwoman."" Applause erupted in the room.

column1: Just minutes later
column2: Jens Spahn threw his hat into the ring as well. It was a spontaneous move with no real plan behind it. The room went silent.

column1: It wasn't coordinated
column2: says a member of the CDU's conservative wing. ""There was a loss of control for a couple of hours on Monday."" Spahn
column3: the conservative wing representative says
column4: ""lost his nerve
column5: adding that ""following every dictatorship
column6: a period of anarchy follows. That's what happened on Monday.""

column1: Merz and his close friend Schäuble have been waiting for a long time for an opportunity to get even with Merkel and to reverse her political course. Few other CDU politicians feel as humiliated by her as those two
column2: both of whom believe that Merkel prevented them from receiving their political dues. Now
column3: they are standing in the way of the chancellor's final political goal: that of retaining control over her own departure.

column1: The two men have been friends for a long time. When Schäuble celebrated his 75th birthday one year ago
column2: Merz wasn't just invited to the official ceremony
column3: but also to the private party for family and friends. Merkel was not. Merz was also among the first to learn that Schäuble no longer wanted to be in the cabinet following last year's general election.

column1: Merz has a lot to thank Schäuble for. Back in 1996
column2: Schäuble installed Merz as the senior conservative on the Finance Committee in German parliament. Four years later
column3: he then ensured that Merz succeeded him as conservative floor leader when he was forced to resign in early 2000 due to his role in the CDU donation scandal.

column1: Schäuble also promoted Merkel
column2: surprising everyone in 1998 by making her the party's general secretary. Everyone assumed that she would remain loyal to Schäuble out of gratitude
column3: but Merkel seized the first chance she got to set out on her own.

column1: In mid-December 1999
column2: just as the party donation scandal was reaching its apex
column3: Merkel published her famous open letter in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung challenging the party to emancipate itself from Helmut Kohl. Schäuble only learned of the existence of the letter once it was published. It was the first wound that Merkel inflicted on him.

column1: He paid her back in his own way. When the question arose two years later whether Merkel would be the chancellor candidate for the conservatives or whether that honor would go to Edmund Stoiber of the Christian Social Union
column2: the CDU's Bavarian sister party
column3: Schäuble supported Stoiber. As did Merz and other senior members of the Andes Pact.

column1: What Merz didn't know
column2: however
column3: is that Stoiber had promised to support Merkel for the position of conservative floor leader after the election. When Merz learned about the deal on the evening of Stoiber's defeat to Gerhard Schröder
column4: he was furious. It was only with significant effort that Schäuble was able to convince him to remain in politics at all -- and Merz was left to serve his hated rival as deputy floor leader.

column1: 'The Woman from East Germany'
Merz never really got over the defeat. In an interview shortly after the 2002 general election
column2: he complained that Merkel had not adhered to an agreement regarding the position of floor leader. But
column3: he added grumpily
column4: he wasn't surprised. After all
column5: he ""knows her in such situations.""

column1: Increasingly
column2: Merz was unable to hide his dislike for Merkel. The fact that ""the woman from East Germany
column3: as he called her
column4: passed by all of her deserving party allies and then even managed to win the Chancellery is something that he saw as a lasting ignominy. In 2009
column5: Merz decided to no longer campaign for re-election in the Bundestag and left politics.

column1: Schäuble's relationship with Merkel likewise worsened quickly
column2: reaching its nadir in the spring of 2004. That year saw the election of a new German president and Merkel had initially supported Schäuble for the position. But then she saw an opportunity to push through a candidate together with the support of the business-friendly Free Democrats as a kind of precursor to joining the party in a future governing coalition. In the decisive meeting of CDU leaders in March 2004
column3: Schäuble made one final effort to turn the tide in his own favor. It isn't wise
column4: he said
column5: ""to allow smaller partners to dictate important decisions."" Everyone knew how difficult it was for Schäuble to toot his own horn
column6: but he badly wanted the office of president.

column1: Still
column2: Merkel wouldn't budge and together with the FDP
column3: she installed the former International Monetary Fund head Horst Köhler in the office.

column1: From that point on
column2: Schäuble was damned to serve in the cabinet of a woman who had destroyed his life's dream. First
column3: he served as interior minister before moving to the Finance Ministry -- and he consistently made it clear that he felt he had better leadership qualities than Merkel.

column1: The depth of the wounds suffered by Merz and Schäuble would occasionally surface in the ensuing years. ""The strategy of putting as many voters from the other side into a coma is likely at an end
column2: Merz said bitingly last year in reference to Merkel's soporific political style. Schäuble
column3: for his part
column4: became more vocal in his criticism the weaker Merkel became
column5: particularly in reference to her refugee policies
column6: the result of which he described as an ""avalanche.""

column1: Following the most recent general election in September 2017
column2: Schäuble elected to leave the cabinet for the position of Bundestag president. That meant that he no longer had to hew as closely to the Chancellery line
column3: a freedom of which he has taken full advantage. Ahead of the state elections in Bavaria and Hesse
column4: he publicly speculated about the end of the Merkel era. ""She is no longer as beyond dispute as she was in the past three
column5: or two-and-a-half
column6: legislative periods
column7: he said. He said he expected the election results would have consequences for national policy and
column8: as such
column9: for the chancellor's standing.

column1: By that point
column2: Schäuble knew that his friend Merz was ready to run for the position of CDU party chairman. Indeed
column3: he didn't just encourage Merz to do so
column4: but also helped him choose the appropriate timing of his announcement. The more quickly he made his announcement following the Hesse election
column5: Schäuble told Merz
column6: the worse it would be for Merkel.

column1: Drei Verlustjahre in Folge - und eine verheerende Bilanz

Die jüngere Bilanz der Deutschen Bank Börsen-Chart zeigen ist verheerend: Drei Jahre in Folge schrieb die Deutsche Bank Verluste; im Kapitalmarktgeschäft - vor der Finanzkrise 2007/2008 eine Goldgrube - fielen die Frankfurter weit hinter die angloamerikanische Konkurrenz zurück; im heimischen Privat- und Firmenkundengeschäft machen ihr Sparkassen

Schlankere Führungsstrukturen sollen die Kosten zusätzlich drücken. column1: Jeffrey Sonnenfeld
column2: Jahrgang 1954

column1: Über Facebook-Chef Mark Zuckerberg hat Sonnenfeld schon einmal den wenig schmeichelhaften Satz gesagt

column1: Jeffrey Sonnenfeld

Sonnenfeld sieht sich nun bestätigt angesichts des Skandals um die Nutzung von Millionen Facebook-Nutzerdaten durch die zwielichtige Kampagnenfirma Cambridge Analytica - und angesichts des verheerenden Krisenmanagements des Konzerns.
Im Interview erklärt der Forscher
column2: warum Zuckerberg zum größten Problem für seine eigene Firma wird.

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: Wie bewerten Sie Facebooks Krisenmanagement im Datenskandal?
Sonnenfeld: Die Leiter des Unternehmens haben die Tragweite des Skandals völlig falsch eingeschätzt. Sie haben es wie ein reines PR-Problem angesehen
column2: aber es geht um den Kern des Geschäftsmodells von Facebook: den Umgang mit Daten.

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: Was lief schief?
Sonnenfeld: Zuckerberg hat Tage gebraucht
column2: bis er sich überhaupt geäußert hat. Dabei ist der Missbrauch von Daten durch Cambridge Analytica doch nur die Spitze des Eisbergs. Facebook hat viele Probleme mit russischen Einflussoperationen
column3: mit Fake News. Ihr eigener Sicherheitschef hat sie 2015 darauf aufmerksam gemacht. Aber das Management hat es bis zuletzt öffentlich geleugnet.

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: Sind das Anzeichen für tiefer liegende
column2: strukturelle Probleme in der Unternehmensführung?

column1: Sonnenfeld: Wir sehen bei der Führung von Facebook eine gewisse Selbstgefälligkeit. Sie glaubt offenbar
column2: über jeden Zweifel erhaben zu sein. Da ist diese kulthafte
column3: fast religiöse Überzeugung
column4: dass alles gut sei
column5: was man tut. Aber keine Technologie ist nur gut. Eine angemessene Verwendung muss garantiert werden
column6: und Facebook ist damit leichtsinnig gewesen. Dennoch bestreitet das Unternehmen jede Verantwortung für den Datenmissbrauch.

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: Zuckerberg hat doch einen langen Post auf Facebook veröffentlicht und Fernsehinterviews gegeben.
Sonnenfeld: Aber es gab nur unzureichende
column2: erbärmliche Antworten
column3: anstelle einer angemessenen Erklärung
column4: warum das Unternehmen nach dem internen Bekanntwerden des Datenmissbrauchs durch Cambridge Analytica keine unabhängige Überprüfung der Vorgänge eingeleitet hat.

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: Woran liegt das?
Sonnenfeld: Das ist der Nachteil
column2: wenn man einen charismatischen Gründer wie Zuckerberg hat
column3: der zugleich Vorstandschef und Chef des Aufsichtsrates ist und auch noch 60 Prozent der Stimmrechte kontrolliert. Es ist das Modell ""Imperator auf Lebenszeit""
column4: fast wie bei Fidel Castro. Solche Strukturen sind nicht nachhaltig
column5: Zuckerberg muss stärker rechenschaftspflichtig werden.

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: Folgt Facebook nicht dem gleichen Skript wie andere große Konzerne mit vergleichbaren Skandalen? Volkswagen zum Beispiel räumt im Abgasskandal ja auch immer nur das ein
column2: was nicht mehr zu leugnen ist.

column1: Sonnenfeld: Bei Facebook geht es nicht wie anderswo nur um inkompetentes Management. Der Konzern war in gewissem Ausmaß Mittäter.
SPIEGEL ONLINE: Wie sähe kluges Krisenmanagement aus?
Sonnenfeld: Nehmen sie zum Beispiel General-Motors-Chefin Mary Barra: Sie kam ziemlich plötzlich auf ihren Posten
column2: weil ihr Vorgänger Gesundheitsprobleme hatte. Kaum im Amt
column3: musste GM fast 30 Millionen Autos zurückrufen...

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: ...wie ging sie vor?

column2: obwohl sie nie zuvor mit einer vergleichbaren Krise konfrontiert war: Sie stellte umgehend ihre besten Leute zusammen. Eine Gruppe fokussierte sich auf den Umgang mit bereits geschädigten Kunden

column5: vor dem Kongress auszusagen. Barra ist damals hingegangen und hat gesagt

column3: die gesamte Lieferkette zu kontrollieren.

column1: SPIEGEL ONLINE: Zurück zu Facebook. Liegen die Probleme in Zuckerbergs Charakter begründet oder eher in der Struktur der Firma?

column1: Grob gesagt ist die Fondswelt derzeit zweigeteilt. Auf der einen Seite stehen die traditionellen Investmentfonds. Dort verwaltet ein Fondsmanager das Vermögen der Anleger
column2: beobachtet Märkte
column3: analysiert Unternehmen
column4: trifft Anlageentscheidungen - und kassiert in der Regel ein ansehnliches Gehalt. Die Kosten
column5: die Anlegern dieser Fonds in Rechnung gestellt werden
column6: sind daher vergleichsweise hoch. Und nur in wenigen Fällen gelingt es den Managern
column7: diese Kosten durch eine entsprechend überragende Performance zu rechtfertigen.

column1: Nicht zuletzt deshalb erfreut sich die zweite Hälfte der Fondswelt großer Beliebtheit: Die börsennotierten Indexfonds
column2: kurz ETFs (Exchange Traded Funds). Diese Fonds verzichten auf aktives Management. Stattdessen folgt ihre Performance präzise der Vorgabe eines zugrundeliegenden Indexes. Der Vorteil: Diese Fonds sind deutlich kostengünstiger und im Durchschnitt auch erfolgreicher
column3: was die Performance angeht. Sie können ihren Benchmarkindex zwar nicht schlagen
column4: schlechter abschneiden als die Orientierungsmarke können sie aber auch nicht.

column1: Der Siegeszug der ETFs verwundert daher nicht. Die Sache hat allerdings einen Haken: Wer seine Wertpapierinvestments ausschließlich auf ETFs aufbauen will
column2: ist schlecht beraten. Denn das sture Nachbilden von Indizes verspricht zwar in etablierten Märkten wie dem deutschen oder dem US-amerikanischen Handel mit Standardaktien den Erfolg. In exotischeren Regionen
column3: speziellen Branchen sowie bei bestimmten Anlagethemen kann jedoch erfahrungsgemäß die Expertise eines erfahrenen Managers durchaus zusätzliche Renditepunkte bringen. Sprich: Dort ist aktives Management gefragt.

column1: Anleger sollten also nach wie vor beide Seiten der Fondswelt im Blick behalten. Oder sie greifen zu einer dritten Variante: Den aktiv gemanagten ETFs.
Deren Prinzip ist ebenso einfach wie einleuchtend: Sie sollen die Vorteile beider Fondswelten miteinander verbinden. Als ETFs
column2: börsengehandelte Fonds also
column3: sind sie beispielsweise praktisch zu minütlich aktualisierten Preisen handelbar. Auch ihre Portfoliobestände werden laufend veröffentlicht (statt lediglich monats- oder quartalsweise). Zudem kann nicht nur die Fondsgesellschaft Anteile dieser ETFs ausgeben
column4: sondern auch deren Handelspartner
column5: so genannte Authorized Participants (APs).

column1: Auf der anderen Seite verfügen diese Fonds über ein aktives Management. Das trifft individuelle und - mehr oder weniger - kompetente Entscheidungen - und kostet naturgemäß mehr
column2: als das passive Management eines Index-ETF. Die Kosten der gemanagten Variante der börsennotierten Fonds dürften damit irgendwo zwischen jenen traditioneller Investmentfonds und passiver ETFs liegen
column3: sagen Marktteilnehmer.

column1: Fonds verstärken Trends

column1: Haldanes Argumentation: ETFs folgen Markttrends

column1: Damit wird eine Diskussion neu entfacht

column2: Merkel and her SPD challenger Martin Schulz appeared open to the Frenchman's ideas of appointing a European finance minister and creating a separate budget for the monetary union. But during the election campaign
column3: the FDP fervently warned against the dangers of opening a ""money pipeline from Germany"" to Southern Europe.

column1: The crucial question now is how Merkel will proceed. During the campaign

column4: of the right-wing Front National. ""In every beginning there is a bit of magic

column1: Now she finds herself in a dilemma. Macron is insisting upon a deal that he has been offering the Germans for months now: France will reform its economy and
column2: in exchange
column3: it expects concessions on the restructuring of the eurozone. The Frenchman is unlikely to give Merkel a reprieve as she struggles to form a government in the coming weeks. To make matters worse
column4: the Frenchman's tight timeline doesn't fit with Germany's schedule. The negotiations for the formation of a new governing coalition are unlikely to even begin before state elections are held in Lower Saxony on Oct. 15.

column1: In early September

column5: adding that Europeans should debate their notions of Europe in a series of ""democratic conventions.""

column1: Macron's goal is to make money available to countries faced with a crisis without subjecting them to the strict conditions required by a program under the European Stability Mechanism (ESM)
column2: the eurozone's bailout fund. To achieve this
column3: he is proposing a separate budget for the eurozone.

column4: though

column1: This fell short of a commitment to Macron
column2: especially considering that the proposals put forward by the Frenchman -- entirely in the tradition of his country -- have taken on massive proportions. His proposed budget would include several percent of the eurozone's GDP
column3: with each percentage point worth approximately €100 billion ($119 billion). It remains to be seen where Macron expects to find the money to finance this. The fear in Berlin is that with his extra budget the Frenchman intends to open the door to permanent transfers and that he intends to finance this with jointly held bonds -- in other words
column4: Eurobonds.

column1: On the other hand
column2: Merkel cannot simply leave Macron hanging forever. The chancellor knows that the current calm in the eurozone could turn out to be deceptive. Spain could slide back into crisis in the wake of Sunday's planned independence referendum in Catalonia
column3: and Italy
column4: the third-largest member of the eurozone
column5: is threatened with the prospect of a party heading its government after next spring's election that is contemplating an exit from the monetary union.

column1: A German Proposal
One way of accommodating Macron has been proposed by German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble
column2: who has been toying with the idea for quite some time now of expanding the ESM into a sort of European monetary fund. ""The German Finance Ministry has the copyright on this
column3: he recently boasted with pride at a meeting of EU finance ministers in Tallinn. The fund would be administered by the ESM. And the new mandate for the ESM would allow Merkel's right-hand man to pursue an old objective
column4: namely that the European Commission
column5: which Schäuble accuses of negligence as the supreme regulatory agency overseeing the Stability and Growth Pact
column6: would have to contend with a powerful rival.

column1: The technocrats in Brussels intend to prevent this at all costs

column3: the Commission intends to present its own ideas
column4: including a proposal for the future of the ESM. During that very same month
column5: leaders of the eurozone countries plan to discuss the matter.

Das chinesische Firmen-Konglomerat HNA wird Großaktionär der Deutschen Bank. HNA hat nach eigenen Angaben Aktien im Wert von 755 Millionen Euro an Deutschlands größtem Geldhaus gekauft und hält damit 3

column4: werden aber auf jeden Fall unter zehn Prozent bleiben""
column5: sagte ein HNA-Sprecher. HNA sehe sich als freundlicher Ankeraktionär: ""Wir haben vollstes Vertrauen in das Management der Deutschen Bank und werden die künftigen Schritte genau beobachten und als Aktionär gegebenenfalls unterstützen.""

column1: HNA ist schon jetzt der drittgrößte Aktionär der Deutschen Bank. Katars Ex-Premier Hamad Bin Jassim Bin Jabor Al-Thani und sein Cousin Hamad Bin Khalifa Al-Thani halten zusammen knapp zehn Prozent der Anteile
column2: der US-Vermögensverwalter Blackrock ebenfalls. HNA ist außerhalb Chinas vor allem als Eigentümer von Fluggesellschaften (Hainan Airlines)

column4: besitzt aber auch eine große Bank- und Immobiliensparte. Ein Deutsche-Bank-Sprecher sagte: ""Wir begrüßen grundsätzlich jeden langfristig orientierten Investor.""

column1: Für die Deutsche Bank ist der Einstieg ein Lichtblick. Das Unternehmen hatte seine Aktionäre lange enttäuscht und viel Kritik für ihr Krisenmanagement geerntet. Seit ein Ende der juristischen Altlasten absehbar ist
column2: hat sich der Aktienkurs aber von knapp 10 Euro auf 18 Euro fast verdoppelt. Die Chinesen setzen auf kräftige Kurssteigerungen: ""HNA sieht die Deutsche Bank als sehr attraktives Investment und möchte das Management als Ankeraktionär dabei unterstützen

column2: his belly protrudes slightly from his blazer. His unkempt hair is ash blond and his blue eyes are constantly in motion. Roman Borisovitch has invited us along on a sightseeing tour of London of a totally different kind.

column3: for example
column4: where the British MI6 secret service used to operate and where a confidant of Vladimir Putin bought two apartments a few years back together with his wife valued at £11.4 million. The money is believed to have originated from dubious deals with Russian oligarchs.

column1: That

column4: and well ahead of Frankfurt -- London is a magnet for money.

Economically
column2: London is as big as Sweden. It generates one-fifth of all British gross domestic product (GDP) and it is the world's largest exporter of financial services. Close to 730
column3: 000 people work in the sector in the city. Some 40 percent of global currency trading is conducted through London
column4: with $2 trillion in volume each day.

column1: Around 250 foreign banks have subsidiaries in London in addition to hundreds of law firms. According to the latest wealth report by residential and commercial property consultancy Knight Frank
column2: London is the most important city for the super rich. No other major city in the world has the concentration of multimillionaires seen here.

column1: And yet all these numbers are insufficient for showing what London really stands for. ""London is pure capitalism
column2: says Martha Boeckenfeld
column3: head of the tradition-rich bank Kleinwort Benson.

column2: even eight years after the financial crisis. They are constantly scrutinized by activists like Borisovitch
column3: by regulators and by finance start-ups seeking to alter the landscape of the very financial system upon which London is so heavily reliant.

column1: And now people in the British metropolis are also discussing the possibility of Brexit and the consequences it might have if the Brits vote to leave the EU on June 23. The vote is representative of a new longing to go it alone at the national level
column2: to turn away from globalization -- a shift in thinking that could plunge London

column1: London has survived wars and terrorist attacks
column2: the stock market crash of 2001 and the global financial crisis of 2008. It emancipated itself from America and kept itself apart from the European currency system. London has adapted to all manner of political
column3: economic and technological changes of the past decades.

column1: The Financial World's Madonna

But one thing continued to grow even after the setbacks: The amount of money that was pouring into the city -- that was then pumped back out into the world via the London Stock Exchange or the more opaque channels of banks and asset managers and invested in whatever could provide the highest returns at that moment.
London is for the financial world what Madonna is for pop music
column2: says Chris Skinner
column3: author
column4: blogger and co-head of the Financial Services Club
column5: a European financial industry network. He's a man who can feel London's pulse. ""The city has reinvented itself over and over
column6: Skinner explains
column7: listing out what makes the megacity so strong: People speak English almost all over the planet
column8: British law is acknowledged and applied in large parts of the industrialized world and London attracts talented
column9: ambitious people. The city is both international and pragmatic.

column1: The Royal Exchange Ground Café
column2: located kitty-corner to the Bank of England
column3: where Skinner is talking about the advantages of London
column4: is one of the places where London's rise to become a global trading center began.

column1: The merchant Thomas Gresham conceived the Royal Exchange -- today home to high-end boutiques and restaurants -- during the 16th century as London's first trading venue for stocks and other goods. As far back as 1695
column2: Londoners complained that the business practices of the traders and brokers was loud
column3: rude and unscrupulous.

column1: From then on
column2: they were required to obtain a license
column3: but back then
column4: as after the most recent financial crisis
column5: the industry adapted
column6: changed and kept going. The traders soon began meeting in the coffee houses surrounding the Royal Exchange.

column1: Global Networking
It was in 1698 in Jonathan's Coffee House that John Castaing first published share prices on a regular basis
column2: says Nikhil Rathi
column3: director of international development at the London Stock Exchange (LSE)
column4: making him something of a conceptual successor to Castaing. Today
column5: there's no longer even a trading room at the London Stock Exchange at Paternoster Square. But its global ambitions is made clear by a giant screen in the atrium
column6: on which trading is visualized by stars in space that flash up and disappear with surges of activity. Like London itself
column7: the LSE has made internationalization a principle. ""Open access is at the core of our strategy
column8: Rathi says. Companies from more than 80 countries have listed their shares in London. No other stock exchange attracts more foreign companies
column9: in part because those companies want to be accessible to the international investors who are here as well. Just under £7 trillion in assets are managed from London.

column1: That kind of global networking is one of the reasons that Deutsche Börse
column2: Germany's stock exchange
column3: is merging with LSE -- in a deal announced in February -- and planning to base the headquarters of their joint holding company in London. If the fusion isn't derailed by a vote in favor of Brexit

column1: Quelle: GFCI
London's success as a financial hub has roots that go back to the Industrial Revolution
column2: which began in Britain. It facilitated an early democratization and a level of societal openness that wasn't as developed in the rest of Europe. Given its advantageous geographical position between the east and the west and the fact it was supplied by a colonial empire built on the back of slavery
column3: London became a massive hub for goods very early on. The financial industry simply established itself on top of those foundations.

column1: But with the decline of British industry in the 1970s
column2: London's rise as a financial center also appeared to have come to an end.

column1: Financial Revolution
Margaret Thatcher set the financial sector's rebirth in motion. With her neoliberal policies
column2: she may never have restored British industry to its former glory
column3: but she did help create the financial revolution in Britain with the sudden ""Big Bang"" series of reforms liberalizing the financial sector. Thatcher provided foreign financial companies with access to the London stock exchange
column4: loosened trading rules and embraced free markets. Some within the conservative London financial elite even thought the reforms went too far. They feared the country's Americanization.

column1: The Americans did come
column2: and so did the Germans and other Continental Europeans. Along with them came the victory march of the shareholder value doctrine -- the alignment of seemingly all business activities in the interests of shareholders.

column1: London opened itself up to this culture to a greater degree than anywhere else -- aggressive investment banking
column2: anything-goes hedge funds -- and thus became the dominant capital market in Europe.

column1: But the ""Big Bang"" also brought London what people in the city dub the ""Wimbledon effect"" -- meaning that people there play hosts to the biggest and best competition
column2: but seldom get top billing themselves. After ""Big Bang
column3: financial institutions from the United States
column4: Germany and Switzerland acquired numerous British commercial banks.

column1: The Big Bang has forced the City to become global

column3: who himself brings together both new and old London. Yarrow is an old-school banker who wears suspenders beneath his powder blue suit and amber-colored cufflinks. He comes from a family of shipbuilders and worked for a long time for Kleinwort Benson

column1: Laissez-Faire Culture
London never sat idly by waiting for the money to come in on its own. The city viewed its own financial expertise to be an exportable product. Still
column2: London lagged behind New York as a distant No. 2 up until the end of the last century. But reactions to the Sept. 11
column3: 2001 terrorist attacks helped London leap ahead of New York for the first time. The US tightened up its immigration rules and raised the hurdles for foreigners seeking to do business in America.

column1: London

column2: though

Vorstand und Aufsichtsrat der Deutschen Bank droht ein offener Konflikt mit wichtigen Investoren auf ihrer Hauptversammlung in knapp zwei Wochen.

Der ISS-Vorstoß ist die bislang gefährlichste öffentliche Kritik an dem Deutsche-Bank-Vorstand seit deren Amtsübernahme im Juni 2012. Zwar hatten wesentliche Aktionäre nach Informationen des manager magazins im Sommer 2014 den Aufsichtsrat und Co-Chef Anshu Jain aufgrund der monatelangen Gewinnschwäche zu einer Generalüberholung der Strategie aufgefordert - allerdings geschah dies abseits der Öffentlichkeit.

Aktionärsberater wie ISS beraten große institutionelle Anleger bei deren Abstimmungsverhalten auf Hauptversammlungen. Weil sie ihre Ratschläge mitunter im Vorfeld mit umfangreichen Studien untermauern
column2: folgen ihnen die Großanleger meist.

column1: Siemens has always had confident CFOs. But Kaeser has been so openly critical that some at the company have already eyed him with suspicion in the past. Others call him authentic. Kaeser himself says: ""It's time for the CEO to tell us where we're going. The CFO's job is to ask how we're going to get there.""
Exactly two weeks after this conversation

column3: he was still commenting on the company's meager quarterly results
column4: and by Thursday he was giving his first interviews.

column1: Now that he has premiered as the new Siemens CEO

column3: one of his deputy chairmen.

column1: The two senior executives have had plenty of experiences of their own

column1: Open Wounds
Companies
column2: like people
column3: also protect themselves and normally hide behind masks of clichés
column4: politeness and discretion. For a few days last week
column5: however
column6: Siemens seemed like an open wound. The dispute between the two old executives -- who can be as vicious as wolves -- quickly became so loud that even Chancellor Angela Merkel made it clear that she wanted to see calm return to Munich.

column1: But calm isn't exactly the forte of Germany's most traditional industrial group
column2: where everything is always a little bigger than among the rest: the orders
column3: the goals
column4: the battles and the disasters. And there have been many of the latter recently

column6: billions in poorly conceived acquisitions

column2: which Siemens does not manage.

column1: The multinational corporation has lost some of its connection to the German people

column3: respected

column1: 'Children in a Sandbox'
This can certainly provide for some entertainment value
column2: especially when even a senior Siemens official says: ""Sometimes people in companies like ours behave like children in a sandbox

column1: To truly understand how last week's showdown came about
column2: it's worth looking back at 2005
column3: when then-CEO Heinrich von Pierer passed the baton to Klaus Kleinfeld. Everything was still in order at the time
column4: and each executive had his designated seat at the boardroom table in Munich. The executives only spoke in turn
column5: and no one was blamed when something went wrong
column6: because the governing collective did not believe in assigning individual responsibility.

column1: Then came Nov. 15
column2: 2006. On that Wednesday
column3: prosecutors and investigators searched about 30 Siemens offices
column4: as well as the homes of top executives. The company had developed a perfectly functioning bribery system over the decades
column5: and until the passage of an anti-corruption law for corporations in 1998
column6: such ""useful expenditures"" were even considered tax deductions in Germany. But even after the law went into effect
column7: Siemens continued with its old practices. Either the company didn't -- or couldn't -- cease to bribe potential customers.

column1: The bribery scandal came as a heavy blow to employees. But the worst thing about it was not the loss of image and self-confidence. The American Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) threatened to blacklist the company
column2: and executives in Munich were worried that this could translate into a substantial loss of contracts worldwide. In those months in early 2007
column3: Siemens' very existence was at stake.

column1: The Doer and the Supervisor
First
column2: Supervisory Board Chairman Heinrich von Pierer had to be disposed of
column3: which Cromme handled. A week later

column6: Löscher boarded the last flight from the United States to Frankfurt
column7: where he met with Cromme the next day. Soon Löscher
column8: who was still with US pharmaceutical company Merck at the time
column9: was the new chief executive at Siemens.

column1: The upshot is that both men came to their jobs more or less accidentally
column2: one as a doer and the other as his supervisor.

column1: Löscher was given the credit for the fact that the entire scandal ""only"" ended up costing the company 2.5 billion ($3.3 billion). As the first Siemens CEO who had been brought in from the outside

column1: But while the Germans were concerned with their own interests
column2: business was booming -- and
column3: along with it
column4: the competition. ""Everyone was relaxing and saving their strength

column1: Löscher cleaned up the mess
column2: recruited new people
column3: restructured the company
column4: emphasized dialogue and left day-to-day operations up to the division heads. It's something he does well -- textbook-style management. It worked

column1: But how does one prescribe a necessary change of course to a global workforce
column2: a shift away from the culture of fear and toward a form of growth that is still based on values? And what exactly are those values?

column1: You feel like you're in one of those fairy tales in which the knight has just killed the dragon. And now he has to capture the princess's heart

column3: breathless
column4: on the bridge to the tower
column5: while the dragon behind us was starting to spit fire again.""

column1: Seeing Black and White in a Sea of Gray
In this phase
column2: Löscher began making his first mistakes. In the spring of 2011
column3: he announced a sales target of 100 billion -- a quarter more than the company had earned by that point. He also said that the return on sales would increase to 12 percent. But he didn't say how and with what means these goals were to be reached. Instead
column4: he presented a cost-cutting program that angered employee representatives.

column1: Löscher's second term began in the summer of 2012
column2: and it didn't begin on a good note. The ICE trains for Deutsche Bahn weren't finished yet. The offshore business in the North Sea had turned into a nightmare. Löscher couldn't hear the dragons yet
column3: but they were already hissing.

column1: Löscher's closest associates say that he operated in binary fashion
column2: like a computer: One. Zero. Question. Answer. Problem? Solution! Black. White. He couldn't see the many shades of gray around him. But Siemens is in fact a gigantic palette of a wide range of gray tones.

column1: The head of a major German corporation is always in a cocoon. As diverse as the external influences are
column2: he remains protected from them. But even after five years at Siemens
column3: Löscher still had almost no confidants to explain the subtleties to him.

column1: 512";"https://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/a-754452.html";2011-04-01;"Irish Banks Fail Stress Tests";"Ireland's banks performed so badly in the latest EU stress tests that the country's last remaining major independent financial institutions will likely be nationalized. The entire banking sector is set to radically shrink
column2: but that might carry significant risks for Ireland's European partners.

column1: Many had thought that Dublin's banks had already hit bottom. But
column2: after the release Thursday of the results of the latest European Union banking stress tests in Ireland
column3: Dublin's financial industry looks more like it has fallen into a bottomless pit.

column1: Three years after the start of the financial crisis
column2: the last of what were once six major Irish banks is now to be taken under the government's wing with the expected nationalization of Irish Life and Permanent (IL&P). The results of the stress tests show that the company needs to raise 4 billion ($5.67 billion) to meet new capital strength requirements. The only path left for the bank is a bailout funded by Irish taxpayers.

column1: Even the Bank of Ireland
column2: of which the government already owns 35 percent
column3: needs an additional 5.2 billion in capital and will likely soon be majority-owned by the state. During the presentation of the stress test's results in Dublin
column4: Irish Central Bank chief Patrick Honohan said it was likely that both IL&P and the Bank of Ireland will be nationalized.

column1: In total
column2: Irish banks require an additional 24 billion ($34 billion) in fresh capital if they are to meet the minimum capital limits needed to withstand a crisis scenario. Together with the 46 billion the Irish state has already pumped into its banks
column3: the preliminary total expense of bailing them out will be a whopping 70 billion
column4: or roughly half of Ireland's GDP.

column1: A Fall Foretold
The stress tests covered four institutions: the Bank of Ireland
column2: Allied Irish Banks (AIB)
column3: the Educational Building Society (EBS) and Irish Life and Permanent (IL&P). Last November
column4: the EU had made the stress tests a precondition for approving Ireland's 85 billion rescue package. As part of the tests
column5: the Central Bank of Ireland and the American financial services company BlackRock played out a number of scenarios testing how hypothetical crisis situations would hurt the banks' balance sheets. Banca d'Italia
column6: Italy's central bank
column7: and the Commission Bancaire
column8: France's banking regulator
column9: oversaw the exercise.

column1: For the first time ever
column2: losses stemming from private mortgages were also figured into the calculations
column3: thus triggering the collapse of IL&P
column4: the only bank that had thus far been spared from the Irish financial earthquake. The bank
column5: which is the country's leading issuer of loans for private homebuilders
column6: will now be forced to seek state support. The bank now has only 19 billion in deposits versus 38 billion in mortgages
column7: making it the worst-capitalized banking institution in Ireland.

column1: For days
column2: the stress tests had already been expected to return negative results. As a precautionary measure
column3: IL&P had suspended trading of its shares on Wednesday
column4: a day after they had dropped to 40 cents a share. Thursday morning saw a 24-hour suspension of trading of shares in the Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Banks as well. The precautionary measures turned out to be prudent.

column1: Hopes for Restructuring Success
The reverberations of the fifth round of bank bailouts in Ireland are also likely to be palpable in the euro zone. With Irish banks unable to secure capital from the markets
column2: the only things left to keep the sector afloat are emergency loans from the European Central Bank (ECB). Still
column3: it is unlikely that the latest development will arouse a whole lot of irritation among other euro-zone member countries
column4: because the EU rescue package already earmarked 35 billion to refinance Ireland's banking sector
column5: which will be more than enough to plug the new 24 billion hole. What's more
column6: Klaus Regling
column7: who heads the EU's temporary rescue package
column8: the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF)
column9: said there was no cause for concern because sufficient funds had already been bookmarked to deal with the latest Irish developments.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: critics are already predicting that this will not be the end of the Irish banking saga. Brian Caplan
column3: editor in chief of the magazine The Banker
column4: told the BBC that the 24 billion was fairly low on the spectrum of market estimates
column5: adding that there were even some experts who calculated that the capital injection would have to be somewhere closer to 55 billion.

column1: Even without any additional surprises
column2: the disastrous state of the banks' balance sheets means that the ECB and the rest of the euro-zone states will have to deal with the Irish banking problem longer than they expected to. The Europeans can only hope that the restructuring plan proposed by the Irish government on Thursday will prove effective.

column1: Efforts to Spread the Pain

The central element in Dublin's plan is the consolidation of the Irish banking sector. The plan foresees having only two banks that offer the full range of services: the Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Banks (AIB). EBS would be folded into AIB. Meanwhile
column2: IL&P would spin off its profitable insurance unit and take it public
column3: but nothing has been said about what would happen with its ailing banking unit. Indeed
column4: only one thing is clear: The state will have to deal with the mess. The other two banks
column5: Anglo-Irish and Irish Nationwide
column6: are already being liquidated.

column1: The plan also calls for the banks to be forced to sell off a large portion of the loans on their books. In order to allow them to avoid having to sell them off at fire sale prices
column2: they will be given several years to do so. Toxic assets that can't be sold will be transferred into special funds. All of these measures are meant to clean up their balance sheets -- and keep them that way. As Finance Minister Michael Noonan says
column3: the point is to cut off all ties to the country's ""toxic banking past.""

column1: At the same time
column2: in its negotiations with the holders of Europe's purse strings
column3: the Irish government is fighting to have euro-zone members share a greater part of the costs for Ireland's banking losses. Their argument is that the real-estate-crazy Irish shouldn't have to shoulder all the blame for the debacle. Partial responsibility
column4: they argue
column5: should be placed on foreign banks -- particularly German ones -- who helped fuel the disaster by allegedly throwing all prudence to the wind during the boom. Based on this line of argumentation
column6: the Irish government is demanding that the private creditors of its banks
column7: of which large foreign banks are the biggest
column8: should share in the losses.

column1: So far
column2: however
column3: Dublin's argument has run up against a brick wall. The greatest resistance has come from the ECB and Germany's federal government
column4: which has represented the interest of the country's banks. The only things the two are willing to discuss are lowering the interest rate on the EU loans and extending their maturity dates. The ECB and the finance ministers of EU states are already negotiating these matters with Irish government officials. But many economists are convinced that Ireland will crumble under the weight of its debts if at least some of the debts aren't forgiven."

column4: musste sich also keinen rigiden Bewerbungsverfahren unterziehen. Genau die sind aber ein großes Hindernis für Geisteswissenschaftler mit Ambitionen in der Wirtschaft.

column1: In Deutschland haben wir einfach eine andere Tradition in der Personalarbeit""

column3: wo es viel stärker auf die Persönlichkeit ankomme. Gänzlich verschließt man sich den akademischen Denkern aber auch in deutschen Firmen nicht: Im Marketing
column4: Personalwesen oder in der Öffentlichkeitsarbeit trifft man immer wieder auf sie. Doch auf diese Bereiche werden Geisteswissenschaftler in Deutschland beschränkt - und beschränken sich selbst.

column1: Unflexible Firmen - und Geisteswissenschaftler stehen sich selbst im Weg

column2: Philosophen oder Literaturwissenschaftler tragen durchaus ihren Teil dazu bei

column4: Professor für Corporate Responsibility an der Uni Witten/Herdecke und von Haus aus Philosoph
column5: attestiert den Geisteswissenschaftlern in Deutschland eine gravierende Skepsis gegenüber der Wirtschaft. ""Viele haben Vorurteile und sind einfach nicht an einer Karriere in der Wirtschaftswelt interessiert."" Geisteswissenschaftler seien eher idealistisch veranlagt und würden sich den Weg in Banken und industrielle Firmen oft selbst versperren.

column1: Trotzdem rücken die Inhalte aus den Wirtschafts- und Geisteswissenschaften teilweise schon näher zusammen. Ökonomie-Fakultäten versuchen immer wieder
column2: Elemente der Geisteswissenschaften wie etwa das Fach Ethik in ihre Studiengänge zu integrieren
column3: mit mäßigem Erfolg
column4: denn Wirtschaftswissenschaftlern gilt Ethik oft als ""Laberfach"". Und umgekehrt? Könnten philologische oder kulturwissenschaftliche Fakultäten nicht auch wirtschaftliche Themen stärker mit einbeziehen und ihre Absolventen so für die Unternehmen attraktiver machen?

column1: Das wäre genau das
column2: was Personaler Anz sich wünschen würde: ""Absolventen geisteswissenschaftlicher Studiengänge haben häufig kein Verständnis für die Welt der Unternehmen und dafür
column3: wie es in der Wirtschaft zugeht
column4: wie eine Firma funktioniert."" Doch auf Seiten von Philosoph
column5: Historiker und Co. tut sich in diese Richtung wenig. ""Geisteswissenschaftler sind einfach lethargischer""
column6: kritisiert Professor Heidbrink von der Uni Witten-Herdecke seine Kollegen.

column1: Experten im Über-den-Tellerrand-Schauen

column2: denn Geisteswissenschaftler könnten dort wichtige Positionen besetzen
column3: sagt Heidbrink. ""Gerade idealistisch-ethisch geprägtes Führungspersonal wird in der Wirtschaft von morgen wichtiger sein denn je.""

column1: Und weil Nachhaltigkeit als Thema immer wichtiger werde
